text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
The following is a description of the material changes to this IRM:

IRM Description of Change Section IRM 5.6.2.1 A new subsection, Program Scope and Objectives, was inserted to provide internal controls information. All following subsections were renumbered. IRM Updated to correct the annual reconciliation date. 5.6.2.4(4) IRM Updated the documents included in the reconciliation. 5.6.2.4(5) IRM Removed the table regarding collateral property 5.6.2.4(7) because guidance will vary based on the National RACS Reconciliation Coordinator. Throughout Replaced all references to “Advisory” with “Civil En- forcement Advice and Support Operations” (CEASO). Throughout Updated citations, IRM references and links. Editorial and grammatical changes made for clarity.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
This supersedes IRM 5.6.2, dated September 27, 2011.

) Program Effectiveness. The program effectiveness is measured by the following review types and by level of management. • Case reviews are conducted by group managers and are recorded in the Embedded Quality Review System (EQRS)(managers) or Quality Review System(NQRS)(Field Quality) to ensure compliance this IRM. • Operational reviews are conducted by territory managers and area directors annually to evaluate program delivery and conformance to ministrative and compliance requirements. • Program reviews are conducted by Headquarters Policy annually to evaluate program delivery and conformance to administrative and pliance requirements. (

) Collateral agreements are monitored by these types of program controls: • ICS open control • Unique serial number • Collateral agreements are input into the Redesigned Revenue ing and Control System (RRACS). The RRACS Unit in Ogden these agreements. • Certain actions relating to collateral agreements that require approval. (

) Frequently used terms within this IRM along with their deﬁnition include: a. Bond: a debt investment in which an investor lends money to an entity which borrows the funds for a deﬁned period of time at a variable or interest rate. b. Escrow Arrangements: an arrangement in which one party deposits an asset with a third person, who, in turn, makes a delivery to another if and when the speciﬁed conditions of the contract are met. c. Mortgage: a legal agreement by which a bank or other creditor lends money at interest in exchange for taking title of the debtor’s property, the condition that the conveyance of the title becomes void upon the payment of the debt. d. Security: a fungible, negotiable ﬁnancial instrument that holds some of monetary value. (

Program Effectiveness. The program effectiveness is measured by following review types and by level of management.

Case reviews are conducted by group managers and are recorded in the Embedded Quality Review System (EQRS)(managers) or National Quality Review System(NQRS)(Field Quality) to ensure compliance with this IRM. Operational reviews are conducted by territory managers and area directors annually to evaluate program delivery and conformance to ad
ministrative and compliance requirements. Program reviews are conducted by Headquarters Policy annually to evaluate program delivery and conformance to administrative and com
pliance requirements.

ing and Control System (RRACS). The RRACS Unit in Ogden monitors these agreements.
Certain actions relating to collateral agreements that require approval.
Frequently used terms within this IRM along with their deﬁnition include:
5.6.2.1.6 (12-08-2020) Terms/Deﬁnitions/ Acronyms

a. Bond: a debt investment in which an investor lends money to an entity which borrows the funds for a deﬁned period of time at a variable or ﬁxed interest rate. b. Escrow Arrangements: an arrangement in which one party deposits an asset with a third person, who, in turn, makes a delivery to another party if and when the speciﬁed conditions of the contract are met. c. Mortgage: a legal agreement by which a bank or other creditor lends money at interest in exchange for taking title of the debtor’s property, with the condition that the conveyance of the title becomes void upon the payment of the debt. d. Security: a fungible, negotiable ﬁnancial instrument that holds some type of monetary value.

Semi-annual veriﬁcation of the Revenue Accounting Control System Area Office Inventory Detail Report (RACS 135) is required. The reports issued by the service center Revenue Accounting Control System (RACS) for March 31 and September 30 will be used for the semi-annual veriﬁcation.

a. Conduct a semi-annual reconciliation value sufficiency review and veriﬁ- cation of all collateral; b. calendar days after receiving the listing; c. Retain a copy of the conﬁrmation memorandum and the Inventory Detail Report (collateral account portion).

) The Chief Financial Office (CFO) requires that Collection provide a balance of seized assets, acquired property, collateral property, and other Annual property for inclusion in IRS’ ﬁscal year end ﬁnancial statements. of (

) Since all balances must be validated, the reconciliation serves to: Holdings • verify and correct asset information, • ensure that CEASO’s recorded asset amounts are current and able (property and documentation exist), and • resolve discrepancies between CEASO records and RACS during process. (

) If all discrepancies are resolved, then adjusted CEASO recorded asset mation will match adjusted RACS. The reconciliation process ensures that most current and supportable information is provided to the CFO. (
) The annual reconciliation of collateral holdings will occur one month prior to the semi-annual reconciliation. (

) The CEASO FIRPTA Coordinator will establish an ICS control to follow-up compliance with the agreement and to monitor the purchaser(s) ﬁling its Investment Real U.S. income tax return. The CEASO FIRPTA Coordinator will secure a Tax Act copy from the applicant and forward it to Examination FIRPTA at the phia Campus for review of the FIRPTA transaction(s). a. The Examination FIRPTA Unit will notify CEASO with the results of review of the FIRPTA transaction(s). b. If there is an outstanding liability, CEASO will issue an NFOI to Field lection to pursue appropriate collection actions. (
) Once all of the FIRPTA transactions are properly reported and all tax paid, CEASO FIRPTA Coordinator will return the collateral to the applicant via memorandum. Close out the ICS NFOI. (
) There are maintenance situations which will require some form of tive CEASO action: Insurance • Proper termination of closing agreement, Tax • Change in the issuing bank guaranteeing the LOC, (

) There are two situations in which CEASO will be required to enforce the LOC: • IRS receives notice from bank that the LOC will be not be renewed the expiration date, • Foreign insurer failure to honor the closing agreement. (
) When it becomes necessary to take enforcement action against the LOC, Chief Counsel will contact CEASO with a request for enforcement action detailed justiﬁcation for such action. (

) Upon notiﬁcation by Chief Counsel, CEASO will advise the QMS Unit of Technical Services in Baltimore, MD of the pending enforcement action providing the name, address, and EIN of the foreign insurance company with the amount of the LOC.

up compliance with the agreement and to monitor the purchaser(s) ﬁling its U.S. income tax return. The Examination FIRPTA Unit will notify CEASO with the results of the review of the FIRPTA transaction(s). b. If there is an outstanding liability, CEASO will issue an NFOI to Field lection to pursue appropriate collection actions. Once all of the FIRPTA transactions are properly reported and all tax paid, CEASO FIRPTA Coordinator will return the collateral to the applicant via memorandum. Close out the ICS NFOI. Upon notiﬁcation by Chief Counsel, CEASO will advise the QMS Unit of Technical Services in Baltimore, MD of the pending enforcement action providing the name, address, and EIN of the foreign insurance company with the amount of the LOC.

) On occasion, an issuing ﬁnancial institution will notify the IRS that a LOC not be renewed and will expire on a speciﬁc date. of Letter of a. The ﬁnancial institution is required to notify the IRS at least

days prior to the state expiration date. b. If the notiﬁcation is timely, mail the appropriate letter to the taxpayer requiring a replacement LOC or risk termination of the election. The closing agreement requires the taxpayer to submit a replacement days prior to the lapse or termination of the existing LOC. Note: The only time a new CDR number is to be issued is in those instances where the issuing ﬁnancial institution has changed. All other changes in LOCs (dollar amount, address change, numbering, etc.) can be treated amendments to the original LOC and a new CDR number is not required. c. If the replacement LOC is not submitted, forward a referral to tion to address any examination potential that would allow the IRS to draw on the LOC to satisfy any tax liability established by (
) If the LOC is not renewed or replaced, and CEASO is advised that there is examination potential, CEASO will, within
calendar days: a. Retrieve the LOC from the safe, b. Return it to the issuing ﬁnancial institution including part
of Form c. Mail the appropriate letter to the taxpayer notifying them of the tion of the election. (
) On an annual basis a compliance check should be conducted on all IRC

(d) entities who are subjects of closing agreements involving LOC. The Monitoring check should ensure that all returns have been ﬁled and paid. The review should closely follow the due date(s) for all ﬁling requirements. (
) If there are compliance issues, the appropriate letter should be mailed to taxpayer addressing the compliance issue and advising them of the risk of mination of the election.

) If the taxpayer does not resolve any issues with the terms and conditions the closing agreement, a letter will be sent to the taxpayer detailing the tions that need to be made, providing a speciﬁc date for response and explaining that the consequence will be termination of the election and potential Examination action. , of Deferral Agreement, this tax deferral agreement will be terminated and deferred tax and interest will be immediately due, unless: a. The covered expatriate, or their U.S. Agent, certiﬁes in writing, prior the expiration of the current agreement, that none of the property or properties that are the subject of the tax deferral agreement have disposed of by sale, gift, disposal in a transaction in which gain is recognized in whole or in part, or by the death of the covered b. The closing agreement requires the taxpayer to monitor and calculate this amount on an annual basis however experience has shown that is not always done and therefore the reminder letter is required. Failure to maintain a LOC at the proper level is grounds for termination of the election.
Once Chief Counsel concurrence is received, send the termination letter to taxpayer. Process the LOC and Form 2276 accordingly.

The covered expatriate, or their U.S. Agent, certiﬁes in writing, prior to the expiration of the current agreement, that none of the property or properties that are the subject of the tax deferral agreement have been disposed of by sale, gift, disposal in a transaction in which gain is not recognized in whole or in part, or by the death of the covered expatriate. If the covered expatriate so certiﬁes, this tax deferral agreement will be renewed and remain in effect for another three years from the date of

certiﬁcation. The covered expatriate may continue to renew the tax deferral agreement every three years. Renewal is contingent upon the covered expatriate increasing the value of the collateral security as described above in (
If the tax deferral agreement is not renewed within the time frame speciﬁed in the tax deferral agreement, the collateral will be applied to the tax liability and interest.
